title: United States radiology imaging and workforce volumes 2017 to 2024: An analysis of 46.4 million imaging examinations from 167 radiology facilities.
abstract: To determine changes in site- and radiologist-specific imaging volumes before, during and after the COVID-19 pandemic from a large, diverse sample of United States radiology practices. Imaging volumes (46.4 million examinations) for 1,571 unique radiologists and 167 United States radiology practices in 19 states (academic [N<=5], community hospital [N=71], multi-specialty clinic [N<=5], freestanding imaging center [N=86], other [N<=5]) participating in the American College of Radiology (ACR) General Radiography Improvement Database (GRID, part of the National Radiology Data Registry [NRDR], which is a CMS-approved Qualified Clinical Data Registry) from December 1, 2017 to February 29, 2024 were analyzed. These dates included baseline, pandemic, and post-pandemic periods. Six modalities were analyzed: computed tomography (CT), mammography, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), X-ray, ultrasound, and positron emission tomography (PET)-CT. National Provider Identifiers (NPIs) were used to track individual radiologists. Changes in workforce number (by NPI), workload (exams/day), NPI attrition, and NPI turnover were calculated by quarter. Of 1,571 radiologists, 671 (43%) were full-time and read â‰¥100 examinations/quarter throughout the baseline period and final study quarter. Mean aggregate change in exams read/day/radiologist from baseline to study end was modest (+0.6% [49.1/day to 49.4/day]). However, the top quartile radiologists (by exam volume) experienced meaningful increases in exams/day (+30.6%; 73.9 exams/day vs. 56.6 exams/day [baseline]) and clinical days worked/quarter (+19.7%; 46.2 days/quarter vs. 38.6 days/quarter [baseline]). The number of working radiologists increased 23.6% (1,094 vs. 885 [baseline]) with substantial turnover. Days worked/radiologist/quarter remained similar (37.2 days vs. 39.1 days, -4.9%). Sharp exam declines during the COVID-19-pandemic were not associated with large reductions in the radiologist workforce. Although the average radiologist read a similar number of examinations per day pre- vs post-pandemic, the top quartile radiologists read 30.6% more examinations per day and work 19.7% more clinical shifts per quarter compared to Q1 2018.
